Yes, there are many organizations that work to protect wildlife from pesticide use and advocating for alternative methods of pest control. Here are a few examples:

1. Pesticide Action Network (PAN): A global network that works to eliminate the use of hazardous pesticides and promote ecologically sound alternatives.

2. The Nature Conservancy: A leading conservation organization, which promotes sustainable land use practices and works to help farmers adopt alternatives to chemical pesticide use.

3. National Audubon Society: An organization dedicated to the conservation of birds and their habitats, which works to minimize the impacts of pesticides on bird populations.

4. Xerces Society for Invertebrate Conservation: An organization that focuses on butterfly and bee conservation, also expanding conservation measures by educating people about impacts on aquatic and terrestrial habitats.

These organizations all accept donations and have volunteer opportunities that you can apply for. Additionally, there may be other local organizations in your area that work to protect wildlife from pesticide use.
